results.title: Changing Times - Changing Schools: Establishing Victorian Secondary Colleges
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal, Warren Thomas and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Educational administrators, teachers, parents and students comment on a range of re-organisation arrangements developed to enable Victorian secondary schools to better respond to todays workforce requirements and the needs of young adults in schooling.

results.title: Computing History: Teaching With a New Technology
results.creator_credit: David Tiley, Penny Robins, Video Projects and Commonwealth Schools Commission (Australia)
results.brief_description: Looks at the use of computers as word-processors and databases in the teaching of history. Programs such as database, newsroom and open database are shown being used. The program also highlights some of the problems, and some of the advantages of using this approach to the teaching of history.

results.creator_credit_for_label: David Tiley, Penny Robins, Video Projects and Commonwealth Schools Commission (Australia)

results.title: Good cleaning fun: housework down the years
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Bob Scarfe, Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: An education officer from the Museum of Victoria looks at a number of “labour saving appliances” used in the home over the last one hundred and fifty years and looks at the development of laundry and kitchen appliances.

results.title: Bicycles down the years
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An introduction to the history of the bicycle, looking at some of the technical and social changes in the past one hundred and twenty years. Bill Sidebottom and Doug McCann from Museum of Victoria present a collection of vintage and veteran bicycles to tell the story.

results.title: Conflict
results.creator_credit: Halina Sztynda, Melanie Guiney and Dept of Conservation, Forests and Land
results.brief_description: Presents the views of the Forest Commission, loggers and conservationists in regard to logging practices in East Gippsland. Allows the viewer to draw conclusions about the attitudes and prejudices of the conservationists and the loggers and saw millers.

results.title: Choice for Year Nine
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria and records how the staff of a regional technical school respond to the attitude problems of Year 9 students.

results.title: Closing the Gap
results.creator_credit: Glenn Mack, Les Mack and Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria. Raises issues of concern for those attempting to bridge the gap between schools and the local community. Depicts the first tentative steps of a small inner-city secondary school.
Filmed at the historic, heritage registered building on City Road, Southbank, formerly the J.H. Boyd Girls’ High School, now (2017) known as the ‘Boyd Community Hub’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Glenn Mack, Les Mack and Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria

Filmed at the historic, heritage registered building on City Road, Southbank, formerly the J.H. Boyd Girls’ High School, now (2017) known as the ‘Boyd Community Hub’.

results.title: Eye of the octopus
results.creator_credit: James Siers, Judy Siers and Sierpinski Films
results.brief_description: Based on the true story of a 13 year old New Zealand boy who lives for a summer with the people of Kiribati, a remote Pacific island and learns their customs. He learns fishing, snorkelling, sailing, and survival techniques. Finally he must capture and kill an octopus in the customary manner.

results.title: But you're a girl
results.creator_credit: Sue Johnston, Julie Ruth and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Shows some of the areas girls have traditionally worked in are no longer certain providers of jobs and then goes on to look at other job options such as trades, apprenticeships and traditionally male dominated professions. Indicates that is is possible for girls and young women to enter these areas, do well in them and enjoy them.

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Dale Baker, Open Channel Productions, La Trobe University, Preston Institute of Technology and Hodja Ed Res Co-op
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.
